children.value:
Linear algebra provides the language and tools for representing and solving
systems of equations, analyzing economic models, and studying optimization
problems. This chapter introduces the basic objects and operations that will
be used throughout the rest of these notes.
is a single number, such as income, price, or an interest rate.

is an ordered collection of numbers. For example, a vector of
outputs from different sectors can be written as

children.html: x=[x1x2⋮xn].x = \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ \vdots \\ x_n \end{bmatrix}.x=⎣⎡​x1​x2​⋮xn​​⎦⎤​.

children.value: is a rectangular array of numbers. For example,

children.html: A=[a11a12a21a22].A = \begin{bmatrix} a_{11} & a_{12} \\ a_{21} & a_{22} \end{bmatrix}.A=[a11​a21​​a12​a22​​].

children.value: Two matrices of the same dimension can be added element by element:

children.html: A+B=[aij+bij].A + B = [a_{ij} + b_{ij}].A+B=[aij​+bij​].

children.value: A matrix can be multiplied by a scalar

children.value: These operations behave much like addition and multiplication of numbers.

Matrix multiplication is defined so that dimensions must be compatible.

children.value: Thus, the inverse matrix allows us to solve systems of linear equations.
Not all matrices are invertible. Non-invertibility typically reflects:
the absence of a unique solution.
